description: User-friendly web-based agents for working with functional genomics and other data. Most are designed with the plant (mainly Arabidopsis) reseacher in mind, but a couple of them can be useful to the wider research community.
name: Bio-Analytic Resource (BAR)

metadata.abstract: © 2016 The Authors The Plant Journal © 2016 John Wiley & Sons LtdIdentifying sets of genes that are specifically expressed in certain tissues or in response to an environmental stimulus is useful for designing reporter constructs, generating gene expression markers, or for understanding gene regulatory networks. We have developed an easy-to-use online agent for defining a desired expression profile (a modification of our Expression Angler program), which can then be used to identify genes exhibiting patterns of expression that match this profile as closely as possible. Further, we have developed another online agent, Cistome, for predicting or exploring cis-elements in the promoters of sets of co-expressed genes identified by such a method, or by other methods. We present two use cases for these agents, which are freely available on the Bio-Analytic Resource at http://BAR.utoronto.ca.
metadata.title: New BAR agents for mining expression data and exploring Cis-elements in Arabidopsis thaliana

metadata.abstract: © Springer Science+Business Media New York 2017.Bioinformatic agents have become part of the way plant researchers undertake investigations. Large data sets encompassing genomes, transcriptomes, proteomes, epigenomes, and other “-omes” that have been generated in the past decade may be easily accessed with such agents, such that hypotheses may be generated at the click of a mouse. In this chapter, we’ll cover the use of bioinformatic agents available at the Bio-Analytic Resource for Plant Biology at http://bar.utoronto.ca for exploring gene expression and coexpression patterns, undertaking promoter analyses, performing functional classification enrichment analyses for sets of genes, and examining protein-protein interactions. We also touch on some newer bioinformatic agents that allow integration of data from several sources for improved hypothesis generation, both for Arabidopsis and translationally. Most of the data sets come from Arabidopsis, but useful BAR agents for other species will be mentioned where appropriate.
metadata.title: The bio-analytic resource for plant biology
